properties.title: NJ Medical Team Flies To Help Injured In Haiti
properties.description: Not Yet Classified &mdash; New Jersey<br/>A team of 10 physicians and surgeons from Cooper University Hospital in Camden has flown to the Dominican Republic, where it will await assignment to earthquake-ravaged Haiti. The doctors left Sunday from Atlantic City International Airport aboard a private jet with 1,200 pounds of medical supplies — the maximum that could be carried. Dr. Anthony Mazzarelli, who's heading the mission, said there were plans for a medical mission to Haiti before the earthquake struck last Tuesday. Mazzarelli also headed a team that assisted after Hurricane Katrina.

properties.title: UN to boost Haiti quake relief force
properties.description: Tetanus, Measles, Meningitis, HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis, Malaria &mdash; Haiti<br/>• Mission to get 3,500 more troops and police   <br />• US helicopters touch down at presidential palace<br/><br/><br/><br/>US navy helicopters landed on the grounds of Haiti's damaged presidential palace today greeted by cheers from earthquake victims as the UN security council voted to send 3,500 extra troops and police to assist in the recovery work.<br/><br/>Haitians jammed the fence of the palace grounds in the capital, Port-au-Prince, as scores of troops took up positions on the lawns of the presidential palace.<br/><br/>"We are happy that they are coming, because we have so many problems," Fede Felissaint, a hairdresser, told the Associated Press.<br/><br/>"If they want, they can stay longer than in 1915," he added, a reference to the start of a 19-year US military presence in Haiti.<br/><br/>The American contingent arrived as the UN security council unanimously approved 3,500 more troops and police to reinforce the UN's 9,000-strong mission in Haiti to ensure security after a magnitude-7 earthquake killed an estimated 200,000 people.<br/><br/>The head of UN peacekeeping, Alain Le Roy, said the extra soldiers were essential because of the "tremendous" number of requests to escort humanitarian convoys, and in case the security situation deteriorates.<br/><br/>Just four blocks from the palace, hundreds of looters rampaged through the city's downtown area. People in one hillside Port-au-Prince district blocked off access to their street with cars and asked local young men to patrol for looters.<br/><br/>Rescuers continued to find survivors seven days afer the earthquake. International rescue teams pulled two Haitian women from a collapsed university building using machinery to cut away debris.<br/><br/>The UN head of humanitarian operations, John Holmes, said not all 15 planned UN food distribution points were up and running yet. The UN World Food Programme said it expected to boost operations to feed 97,000 people on Monday but needed 100m prepared meals over the next 30 days. The US military says it can now get 100 flights a day through the airport – up from 60 last week – but still could do with more. Troops parachuted pallets of supplies to a secured area outside the city yesterday  rather than clog the airport.<br/><br/>The French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, praised the "essential role" of the US, moving to defuse tension between the US and other countries in the confusing scramble to co-ordinate the enormous relief effort.<br/><br/>Sarkozy said France was "fully satisfied" by the co-operation between the US and France, and acknowledged the "exceptional mobilisation of the United States on Haiti's behalf".<br/><br/>The spread of disease has become a major concern in Haiti, medical experts saidtoday, as relief groups struggled to speed up the delivery of supplies to hungry and thirsty earthquake survivors.<br/><br/>Medical experts said many survivors had multiple fractures and internal injuries. Medical teams at mobile hospitals that have been overwhelmed by the casualties warned of the immediate threats of tetanus and gangrene and the spread of measles, meningitis and other infections.<br/><br/>In Haiti, where Aids, tuberculosis and malaria are rampant, children are malnourished and hygiene is already a challenge, the quake has added potentially lethal infections, broken bones, internal injuries and other health complications.<br/><br/>"By any stretch of the imagination it is going to be incredibly difficult. The population in Haiti was already vulnerable and faced enormous health threats," one expert said.<br/><br/>Despite reports of lawlessness, US military officials said violence was isolated and not impeding the aid mission.<br/><br/>As the US military and relief groups struggle to speed up delivery of aid, thousands were leaving the capital, having lost patience with the massive but ponderous aid effort. Most of those fleeing said they were heading to small farms run by relatives.<br/><br/>"We've got no more food and no more house, so leaving is the only thing to do," Livena Livel, a 22-year-old street vendor, told Associated Press. She was going to her father's house near the town of Les Cayes, four hours south of Port-au-Prince.<br/><br/>"At least over there we can farm for food," she said, carrying her one-year-old daughter, Othmeline.<br/><br/>Livel and the six relatives leaving with her said they'd scraped together the last of their money to pay for the trip. With petrol scarce, bus drivers have ramped up fares, forcing some to pay more than three days' wages for a seat.<br/><br/>HaitiNatural disasters and extreme weatherHealthInternational aid and developmentMark Tran<br/>guardian.co.uk &copy; Guardian News & Media Limited 2010 | Use of this content is subject to our Terms & Conditions | More Feeds

properties.title: Haiti faces heightened malaria risk: global ranking
properties.description:
Malaria &mdash; Haiti<br/> Search All Our Sites - Powered 
 Haiti faces heightened malaria risk: global ranking 
 Already at high risk for malaria, Haiti faces an even greater likelihood that the disease will spread after the January 12 quake that killed at least 70,000, according to an assessment obtained on Tuesday by AFP. "It is highly probable that the prevalence of malaria will increase in the wake of the disaster," said Fiona Place, a researcher at British risk analysis specialists Maplecroft and co-author of the Malaria Risk Index. "Overcrowding in the camps for the displaced, inadequate shelter and sanitation, overburdened medical facilities, ruptured sewer systems -- all these factors provide favourable conditions for the breeding of malaria vectors," Place told AFP. Improvised use of open-air catchments for rainwater also make it easy for the mosquitoes that carry the disease to multiply, she said. Containing malaria's spread would partly depend on how fast aid agencies could provide long-lasting insecticidal nets, set up basic health care and distribute drugs and supplies, she added. Dysentery, measles and other mosquito-borne diseases such as dengue fever, as well as TB, influenza and other respiratory infections already lurk in Haiti and have ample means to spread among those who are weak or in poor health, living in the street or in cramped rooms, experts say. The Maplecroft Index ranks more than 100 countries most affected by malaria, based on 10 criteria including the number of cases, deaths of children under five, use of nets and distribution of drugs. Capacity to contain an outbreak is also taken into account. All but six of the 40 countries hit hardest are in Africa. Those most in peril, in the "extreme" risk category, are Democratic Republic of Congo, Angola, Yemen, Burkina Faso, Togo, Comoros and Chad. Prior to the 7.0 Richter Scale earthquake Haiti ranked 34th, which put it in the "high" category of risk. The largest non-African country at high risk is Pakistan, according to the study. "Its rating falls down most on malaria prevention, in terms of its distribution of nets, indoor residual spraying and medicinal treatment," Place said. Pakistan is also susceptible because its vast irrigation networks and monsoon rains provide ideal breeding grounds for mosquitoes. An estimated 243 million cases of malaria around the world in 2008 led to almost 863,000 deaths, according the World Health Organisation (WHO). Almost 90 percent of those deaths were in Africa, and 85 percent were children under five years of age. The remaining 10 percent of fatalities were evenly divided between Southeast Asia and the eastern Mediterranean. The use of insecticide-treated nets for sleeping and the careful use of indoor insecticides are cheap and effective ways of preventing infection, recent initiatives have shown. Africa is most vulnerable because of the combined factors of favourable conditions for the breeding of mosquitoes and inadequate resources to protect the population from the disease's spread. The high prevalence of HIV/AIDS, which depresses the immune system, increases susceptibility to malaria as well. Global warming is also set to push malaria into new regions, according to scientists. A temperature rise of only 1.0 to 2.0 degrees Celsius (1.8 to 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit) would be enough to facilitate the migration of malarial mosquitoes further north, particularly in Africa, they say.. Sections of the information displayed on this page (dispatches, photographs, logos) are protected by intellectual property rights owned by Agence France-Presse. As a consequence, you may not copy, reproduce, modify, transmit, publish, display or in any way commercially exploit any of the content of this section without the prior written consent of Agence France-Presse.

properties.title: Earthquake Devastation Reaches Far and Wide
properties.description:
Environmental &mdash; Petit Goâve, Ouest, Haiti<br/> Support Our Troops, Read Their Stories 
 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
 Attacks on Tea Party Movement Backfires! 
Petit Goave, a costal city located about 33 miles west of Port-Au-Prince, was also devastated by the 7.0-magnitude quake that struck Haiti last Tuesday. With approximately 60 percent of homes and buildings leveled in destruction, this city is largely in ruins. According to Radio Heritage radio reporters, nearly one-third of the 120,000 population may have perished in the quake, including political leader, Hubert De Ronceray, and Haiti 's Chief Justice, Rock Cadet. 
The immediate needs of the city are enormous. The population has yet to receive the international aid or any significant resources that are being diverted to Port-Au-Prnce. Mayor Justal Marc Roland and other city officials are pleading for help as desperate residents face a sixth day with little food, water or medical care.

properties.title: Outside Haiti's capital, help trickles in - latimes.com
properties.description:
Environmental &mdash; Léogâne, Ouest, Haiti<br/> Outside Haiti's capital, help trickles in 
 In Leogane, residents have seen Argentine and Spanish teams. But the city of 130,000 is in desperate need of food and water. 
 Patients get care at a cllinic in Leogane nearly one week after the earthquake hit the rural town.
 Reporting from Leogane, Haiti - 
 Only the goats risk the cool shade of the century-old colonnades left standing in this provincial capital. The people have hauled themselves and their possessions into the middle of the dirt roads, away from the fallen storefront arches and tin roofs that now rest on piles of brick like crumpled hats. Leogane looks like an archaeological dig overrun by squatters who wait for food, medical attention and shelter from the sun and coming rain. International aid is starting to pour into Port-au-Prince, two hours to the east. On Monday, four ships carrying 2,200 Marines anchored off the coast and began ferrying supplies and personnel ashore. There were scattered reports of looting and gunfire in the capital, but U.N. officials said the relief effort was gaining momentum. And international teams were still finding victims alive under the rubble. In Leogane, hub of Haiti's sugar cane country, residents have seen just an Argentine medical team and the Spanish Red Cross, which is assessing sanitation and water needs here. In a city of 130,000, only one well is pumping water -- no faster than the flow of a garden hose. And it's not drinkable. Residents have given up expecting that any of those still trapped in the rubble will be rescued. After the initial grief and fear, there is a strange pause in the story of last Tuesday's earthquake. People here can smell the inevitable. Jean Robert Senecharles, a thin 35-year-old with watery eyes, said he jumped out of his second-story apartment when the quake hit. The house went down as fast and irrevocably as he did, leaving a large extended family headed by Marie Eve Dupont sandwiched between two slabs of concrete. There were small openings between the layers, but nothing anyone could get more than an arm into. They heard no voices. And when the smell came, they had no choice. "We filled it with dirt," he said. In Leogane, Jacmel and other towns surrounding Port-au-Prince, access is difficult, and the critical first days of the relief effort are waning. The historic sites -- sleepy, rundown vestiges of the old French plantation colony -- are quickly matching the squalor of the capital. The road to Leogane is fractured and rippled in places where the magnitude 7.0 quake caused the earth to shift. Storefronts, houses and police stations along the way have crumbled. Beyond them, the green sugar cane fields shimmer in the sun. Leogane residents are ripping wood and tin off fallen structures, quickly turning parks and fields, even roads, into shantytowns. "Take me to your country!" a woman shouted as a reporter walked by. Marie Elmera Surme's house did not fall, but it's deeply cracked, and she doesn't want to go in. So she sat outside with her remaining food -- three bags of rice and some vegetable oil -- as people hammered scraps of wood in her street. She wondered what she was going to do. "What are we going to rebuild with?" she asked. "If we don't get help, we're going straight to the boats. America is going to be flooded with kanters

properties.title: Church leader: Quake will crowd outlying areas | thetimesherald.com | The Times Herald
properties.description:
Environmental &mdash; Jérémie, GrandʼAnse, Haiti<br/> Your browsers security settings are preventing some features from appearing. See instructions for fixing the problem. 
 Church leader: Quake will crowd outlying areas 
Group returns from Haiti after 3-week stay to help with school 
Gotham, the pastor at First United Methodist in St. Clair, arrived home Tuesday after spending nearly three weeks in Jeremie, Haiti. 
Jeremie is about 120 miles from Port-au-Prince, where most of the casualties and structural damage was centered, along with much of the world's attention after the Jan. 12 disaster, which might have killed 200,000, injured 250,000 and left 1.5 million homeless.

properties.title: Aftershock terrifies desperate Haitians anew
properties.description:
Not Yet Classified &mdash; Haiti<br/>PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) &ndash; A frightening new aftershock Wednesday forced more earthquake survivors to live on the capital's streets or sent them fleeing to perhaps even worse conditions in the countryside.<br/><br/>
A flotilla of rescue vessels, meanwhile, led by the U.S. hospital ship Comfort, converged on the capital. They are helping fill gaps in still lagging global efforts to bring water, food and medical help to hundreds of thousands of people who are surviving in makeshift tents or simply on blankets or plastic sheets under the tropical sun.<br/><br/>

properties.title: Haiti earthquake creating a generation of amputees, doctors warn
properties.description: Not Yet Classified &mdash; Haiti<br/>In overwhelmed hospitals of Port-au-Prince, number of patients having limbs removed indicates a future national crisis<br/><br/>When the earthquake struck Haiti last Tuesday Melene Samedi was shopping for shoes in downtown Port-au-Prince. As the ground began to shake, she froze. A piece of concrete, ripped off a building by the force of the quake, struck her leg, fracturing the bone and wrenching it through her skin. Bystanders rushed the 29-year-old to Port-au-Prince's Hôpital de l'Université but it was too late. The following day surgeons were forced to amputate, just below the knee.<br/><br/>"I don't have a job and I don't have the house. And now this," lamented her husband Schiller Polycarpe, 27, standing by his wife's tatty bed in an improvised ward in the hospital car park. "There is no help from the government.<br/><br/>As Port-au-Prince's largest hospital, the Hôpital de l'Université, or HUEH, has borne the brunt of casualties from the earthquake and doctors are struggling to cope with the seemingly endless stream of new arrivals.<br/><br/>More than a week after the earthquake the HUEH is at the centre of a health catastrophe that many surgeons believe will leave as many as 200,000 Haitians without at least one of their limbs. Aid agency Médecins Sans Frontières this week claimed that the last time surgeons carried out so many amputations was during the Crimean war.<br/><br/>"We are in big trouble," admitted Dr Philip Guilleu, a volunteer surgeon from New York, who said he had personally performed 30 amputations during the last few days. "It is overwhelming."<br/><br/>Even before passing through the hospital's green iron gates, it is easy to sense what lies ahead. In the street outside, hundreds of Haitians cluster around fresh-faced US soldiers clutching M16 assault rifles. The men beg for their families to be admitted to the hospital. The women clutch pieces of orange peel to their noses to mask the stench of the decomposing bodies that have been abandoned on the cracked pavement or are still buried in the rubble of surrounding buildings.<br/><br/>Move through the gates and the true extent of the crisis becomes clear. Hundreds of seriously injured patients and their relatives pack into the hospital's narrow car park. In the scorching midday sun, they lie on battered school desks, filthy mattresses and ageing hospital beds. Many have lost one or more limbs. Others have been badly deformed by falling rubble. Nearly all await surgery in one of HUEH's five operating theatres.<br/><br/>On Wednesday the queue was more than 1,000 patients long. Among them was an unidentified female patient whose lips had been almost completely shorn off by falling debris. "She's got an infection and she's got maggots in there," said Daniel Wiersma, a 24-year-old nurse from Michigan, as he peeled back her bandages.<br/><br/>"I call this war surgery," said Dr George Bouttin, a 73-year-old surgeon from Fort Lauderdale, Florida, who estimates that 95% of those coming in with crushing injuries were having to undergo amputations, partly as a result of infections. "It is guillotine-type amputation." Another of HUEH's emergency recruits, Jean-Paul Bonnet, an American GP, said the US government urgently needed to intervene to help Haiti's new generation of amputees. "There will have to be rehabilitation centres. We will have to train these people to walk again. We will have to train these people to survive again," he said.<br/><br/>"Ironically, if we can find any good out of the war in Iraq perhaps it is the advances in helping amputees … Hopefully those nine years of education will have trained us enough to help this poor&nbsp;country.<br/><br/>"Bring us the technology. Bring us the prostheses. Bring us those people who know how to train these people to function and walk again."<br/><br/>As if the appalling injuries on display were not enough, doctors say they are now having to contend with looting. Following Wednesday's aftershocks, which struck at around 6am, the hospital's guards fled, fearing another big earthquake. Immediately the crowds outside poured through the unguarded gates towards the main building.<br/><br/>"They came into our operating rooms and stole whatever they found," said Bouttin. "The oxygen tanks were gone. Everything was gone. I understand why they steal … but they steal useless things for them. I mean, what are they going to do with an oxygen tank? What are they going to do with intravenous antibiotics?"<br/><br/>With surgeons continuing to perform amputation upon amputation, Samedi and her family were left to reflect on their future in "section four", where the only privacy comes in the shape of a black tarpaulin draped over her bed and where the stench of putrefying flesh hangs in the air.<br/><br/>What would the family do now? "Now&nbsp;we will wait," Polycarpe, who had spent the previous eight days sleeping on the concrete floor next to his wife, said bluntly.<br/><br/>His father-in-law, 56-year-old Neider Samedi, was more reflective. "God gives and God takes," he said of his daughter's injuries.<br/><br/>And what had he said to his God since the earthquake? He shrugged. "Merci."<br/><br/>HaitiNatural disasters and extreme weatherInternational aid and developmentHealthTom Phillips<br/>guardian.co.uk &copy; Guardian News & Media Limited 2010 | Use of this content is subject to our Terms & Conditions | More Feeds

properties.title: Al Jazeera English - Americas - Disease fears in quake-hit Haiti
properties.description:
HIV/AIDS, Malaria &mdash; Haiti<br/> Tuesday, January 19, 2010 09:38 Mecca time, 06:38 GMT 
 As a massive international aid effort gathers pace in earthquake-hit Haiti, medicals teams have said they are overwhelmed by the number of casualties and fear the worst is yet to come as infection and disease take hold. 
The Caribbean nation of over nine million people was already struggling with increasing Aids infections, as well as outbreaks of tuberculosis and malaria before the quake struck. 
 Thousands of children were malnourished, hygiene was a daily challenge, and according to experts, the quake may create one of the worst medical disasters. 
Haitian officials have said the death toll from Tuesday's magnitude 7.0 quake is likely to be between 100,000 and 200,000, but no one has yet begun to get a count of injuries.

properties.title: WSVN-TV - 81 Haitian orphans arrive at MIA
properties.description:
Diarrhea &mdash; Miami<br/> MIAMI (WSVN) -- Some of the smallest survivors of the earthquake in Haiti have begun arriving in South Florida. 
Friday morning, Miami International Airport was the first stop in what will be new lives for 81 orphans from Haiti arriving in the United States. Their adoptive parents had expected to wait months, even years to bring their little ones home, but the disaster in Haiti highlighted the need to get them out of the danger zone. 
Jennifer Ebenhack adopted three Haitian orphans who were carried through customs, many in the arms of customs agents. &quot;Only God can make something so miraculous out of a horrible nightmare,&quot; she said. 
Justin is one of Ebenhack&#39;s newly adopted children who will join her two other biological children in the family. &quot;Our adoption was done, and we got to go here, to the U.S., and I was very, very excited,&quot; he said. 
They are young, but they understand what they have left behind and notice life has already changed. &quot;When I was in Haiti, when I was driving on the road, and whenever there&#39;s a bump, I get very sick, but over here, the roads are much smoother, and I don&#39;t get really sick,&quot; said Daphne, who was also adopted by Ebenhack.

properties.title: CBS4's Scouten And Bernard Reflect On Haiti
properties.description: Not Yet Classified &mdash; Haiti<br/>CBS4's Ted Scouten and photojournalist Jim Bernard returned from Haiti on Friday after seeing firsthand for more than a week just how truly devastated the earthquake-stricken country is. For both Ted and Jim, the images will stay with them for a lifetime, both the stories of survival, and the unimaginable images of death.

properties.title: Immediate Medical Aid Need in Carrefour
properties.description: Not Yet Classified &mdash; Carrefour, Haiti<br/>The brother of HABNET Member Rouandy Pascal is in Carrefour, Haiti.  He reports that people around him are badly injured.  Some of them are cutting off their own limbs in order to avoid infections; they're doing without any anesthesia.  The brother, Eddy Pascal is located at Arcachon 32.  He maintains that there has been no rescue efforts whatsoever in that area.  He and others are in dire need of immediate assistance.

properties.title: NYC AIDS Activist To Cut His Hair To Benefit Haiti
properties.description: HIV/AIDS &mdash; New York City<br/>A New York City activist is auctioning off his 14-inch ponytail to benefit a temporary HIV/AIDS clinic in Haiti. Charles King is president and chief executive of Housing Works in Manhattan. The organization provides housing, health care, meals, case management, counseling and job training. It helps thousands of homeless or low-income New Yorkers living with HIV/AIDS. King will sell his trademark, 14-year-old ponytail at a Feb. 23 charity event. Tickets to "Shear Madness" are $75, $120 and $240.

properties.title: The Associated Press: Health crisis in Haiti enters a deadly new phase
properties.description:
Diarrhea, Respiratory Illness &mdash; Haiti<br/>&ndash;
 1 day ago 
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti &#x2014; Fourteen-month-old Abigail Charlot survived Haiti's cataclysmic earthquake but not its miserable aftermath. Brought into the capital's General Hospital with fever and diarrhea, little Abigail literally dried up. 
"Sometimes they arrive too late," said Dr. Adrien Colimon, the chief of pediatrics, shaking her head. 
The second stage of Haiti's medical emergency has begun, with diarrheal illnesses, acute respiratory infections and malnutrition beginning to claim lives by the dozen.

properties.title: need water at hospital
properties.description:
Not Yet Classified &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>Project Medishare for Haiti is working since the morning after the earthquake. It began with a 11 person trauma team and over the past weeks it has continued its massive coordination with over 5 flights transporting over 150 doctors, nurses and rescue workers not including excessive amounts of medical supplies already on site in Haiti along with facilities being consolidated for air cargo shipments. All efforts are being coordinated from Jackson Hospital through Dr. Green&acirc;s emergency execution team.

Our field hospital is set up at the airport and consists of 150 doctors and 170 to 250 patients. &Acirc;&nbsp;We are now consuming 1500 Liters of drinking water and 4000 Liters of tap water a day. &Acirc;&nbsp;For now we have exhausted our donation contacts and need help from your organization.

properties.title: Possible IDP situation in Croix-des-Bouqets
properties.description:
Not Yet Classified &mdash; Croix-des-Bouquets, Haiti<br/>I have been forwarded an e-mail by a member of the Haitian Diaspora outlining the situation of 1500 children and their families in Croix-des-Bouquets (zone Li Lavoix) who are desperately in need of: food (specifically baby food and formula), water, medicine (anti-diarrhea, antibiotics, hygienic supplies, and anticoagulant), tents and, flashlights.

This e-mail appears to be circulating widely on the internet today (2/10/10) but I did not see it reported here after searching a .csv file of Ushahidi reports for the last 10 days. 

The e-mail also states that Haitians receiving medical treatment in the Dominican Republic have undergone unnecessary amputations and other medical procedures.  

The report originated with Mr. Carl Telemaque. His phone number is 3711 - 1771 but he may soon loose power or service.

***THIS IS MY BEST GUESS AT LOCATION AND IS NOT PART OF THE ORIGINAL MESSAGE***
After visually inspecting the most recent (1/21/10) imagery in Google Earth I would guess that the location of the group is the large IDP camp to the immediate SE of the cemetery. I have attached a screen shot of the location in OSM but didn't wan't to pinpoint it on the map since I'm not sure.

properties.title: Tents Needed
properties.description:
Not Yet Classified &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>My name is Bill Manassero and we have a mission called Child Hope International (childhope.org) in the Delmas 75 region of Port-au-Prince.  We have an orphanage, feeding program and medical clinic that serves a poor ravine community in this area.  Out of necessity, we have had to open two tent city areas to help the most vulnerable in our area (pregnant women, families with small children, and those with special needs).  We are hoping you may have 20 ShelterBoxes or similar waterproof tents available to help out these desperate people.  Is that possible?

Please let me know.  We would be happy to pick-up or whatever is necessary to make it easier for you. You may email me back or call me at 3734-9474.

Thank you for all you are doing for the people of Haiti.

God bless.

bill manassero

properties.title: UM Receives $500,000 From Clinton/Bush Haiti Fund
properties.description: Not Yet Classified &mdash; Haiti<br/>The Clinton/Bush Haiti Fund has awarded $500,000 to a University of Miami project that's charged with running a 240-bed tent hospital at the edge of the Port-au-Prince airport. It was announced Monday that the UM's Global Institute/Project Medishare had received the grant for its efforts to care for injured earthquake patients. The effort is led by Barth Green, M.D., a professor and chair of the neurological surgery unit. Green led the first medical team into Haiti's capital a day after the earthquake struck on January 12th.

properties.title: 2010 Atlantic Hurricane Season Will Increase Infectious Disease Risk in Haiti
properties.description: Environmental &mdash; Haiti<br/>The onset of the 2010 Atlantic hurricane season on June 1st increases the risk of infectious disease activity among earthquake-affected populations in Haiti. A hurricane making landfall in Haiti will bring with it mass precipitation resulting in flooding and stagnant water collection. Saturation of grounds supporting temporary shelters for earthquake survivors will intensify already acute sanitation problems leading to increased exposure of persons to human and animal waste products. This presents an ideal trigger for increased diarrheal disease occurrence, in addition to water-borne illnesses including leptospirosis and typhoid. Similarly, flooding of grounds previously under drought conditions may increase the risk...

properties.title: Acute Respiratory Infections Main Cause of Morbidity
properties.description: Diarrhea, Respiratory Illness &mdash; Haiti<br/>According to an OCHA report published on February 11, Haitian Ministry of Health surveillance data indicates that acute respiratory infections are the main cause of morbidity [in Haiti]. The data was not further sub-categorized by age; it is our assessment diarrheal disease in children is likely underestimated by current surveillance data.

properties.description: Diarrhea, Respiratory Illness &mdash; Haiti<br/>Updated 0216 GMT, 16 FEB 2010 Disruptors Op Notes- Disruptors Surveillance Grid Status. Open dissemination of information from formal medical surveillance has not occurred to our knowledge and has been highlighted as a critical point of concern. Further, one major NGO on the ground in Haiti refused to share information regarding infectious disease events they were observing in children. It is our assessment this reflects current gaps in international agreements for what constitutes "critical information" considered mandatory to share openly with the humanitarian response community. This lack of broader information sharing and dissemination prevents realization of a fully efficient and...

properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Haiti<br/>We interviewed a ground medical team consisting of missionaries and physicians who have a long history of working in Haiti; they returned a couple of days ago from the coastal areas north of PAP. In contrast to Saint-Marc, structural damage due to the earthquake was minimal. properties.title: Haiti Epidemic Advisory System (HEAS) SitRep: UPDATED 20 FEB
properties.description: Diarrhea, Environmental &mdash; Haiti<br/>Updated 0510 GMT, 20 FEB 2010 Biosurveillance Grid Status. Two key issues have been identified with clarity now. Formal surveillance data is coordinated and authorized for release by the Haiti Ministry of Health (MOH). CDC and PAHO support the Haiti MOH in accordance with international agreements and thus must respect Haitian government's decision whether to release information. The second issue is independent of the political situation, where some major NGOs have refused to contribute to biosurveillance. The biosurveillance grid will remain suboptimal until information is shared openly and in a timely manner. Meteorology. See above for seasonal precipitation and temperature...

properties.title: Hyperendemic Transmission of Dengue and Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever Presentation in Haiti
properties.description: Dengue Fever, Hemorrhagic Fever &mdash; Haiti<br/>The risk of dengue infection in responders was discussed in some detail in a prior post. This post focuses on hyperendemic dengue transmission in the indigenous Haitian population. The attached study examined 210 children aged 6 to 13 from the Lekol Basil Moreau School, Bizoton, Carrefour Borough, Port-au-Prince, Haiti in June 1996. Dengue hemorrhagic fever is typically seen in indigenous children in endemic areas. Three pediatricians were interviewed from University of Haiti General Hospital in Port-au-Prince with continuous experience of up to 16 years. These physicians reported seeing no patients with symptoms consistent with dengue hemorrhagic fever. DEN-1, -2, and...

properties.title: Malaria Transmission in Haiti
properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Haiti<br/>Cholorquine-sensitive P. falciparum is the predominant strain (>90%) in Haiti and is transmitted primarily by the Anopheles albimanus mosquito. A. albimanus breeds in hoof and footprints, ditches, and rice fields. More than 80% of rice fields in Artibonite Valley sampled contained larvae in a survey by Caillouet, Keating, and Eisele in November 2006 (see attached): The minor rainy season begins in March, peaking in May. The major rainy season begins in August, peaking in October. Transmission of malaria is seasonal in Haiti, peaking typically in November: Transmission has been reported to be localized to certain villages and intense. A seroprevalance...

properties.title: Fort Royale: Measles and Mumps Reported by Rush Physicians
properties.description: Measles, Mumps &mdash; Haiti<br/>Although there has been no confirmed cases of measles or mumps reported through formal medical surveillance in Haiti, a physician from Rush University Medical Center deployed with International Medical Corps reported seeing one case of measles and a colleague who saw two cases of mumps in siblings.

properties.title: Typhoid Fatality Reported in IDP Camp in Port-au-Prince
properties.description: Typhoid &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>A photojournalist reports a fatality due to typhoid in one of the PAP IDP camps. No report of increased cases.

properties.title: Flooding in Les Cayes
properties.description: Environmental &mdash; Les Cayes, Sud, Haiti<br/>Les Cayes, located in southwestern Haiti, did not experience damage from the earthquake as did Port-au-Prince. However, over this weekend 3,000 were evacuated to higher ground and 13 were killed due to heavy rainfall and flooding to a height of 5 feet. One hospital was forced to move 400 patients to higher floors because the ground floor was under water. As discussed in prior posts, flooding does occur before hurricane season as part of the normal minor rainy season in Haiti, which begins in March.

properties.title: Haiti Epidemic Advisory System (HEAS) SitRep: UPDATED 1 MAR
properties.description: Diarrhea, Environmental, Swine Flu H1N1 &mdash; Haiti<br/>Updated 1750 GMT, 1 MAR 2010 Biosurveillance Grid Status. Formal medical surveillance is currently providing a partial picture of the ground situation. There have been problems with data collection such as reporter fatigue and consistency in reporting. We have noted several key diseases reported through informal surveillance not captured in the formal reporting surveillance process. To-date, operational integration between the two processes has not occurred. Meteorology. See above for seasonal precipitation and temperature curves, respectively. properties.title: Medical Team Treating Patients in Delmas Reports Malaria and Diarrhea Cases
properties.description: Malaria, Diarrhea &mdash; Delmas, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Delmas, Ouest Department Disease Entity: Malaria, non-specified diarrheal disease Volunteers from a non-profit organization based in Florida returned to the United States from Haiti after a four-day deployment to provide treatment and medical supplies to earthquake survivors living in temporary shelter on a golf course in Delmas. It is reported that there are up to 40,000 individuals living in tents at this site. The medical team indicates they treated nearly 800 patients for diarrhea, as well as skin and parasitic infections. They also reported treating cases of malaria based on symptoms observed among patients.

properties.title: Responders Treat Cases of Tetanus, Malaria and Gastrointestinal Infections at St. Francis de Sales Hospital
properties.description: Tetanus, Malaria, Gastroenteritis &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Port-au-Prince Disease Entity: Malaria, tetanus, unspecified gastrointestinal infections A disaster response team from California deployed to Haiti for a seven-day stay reported that as of 1 March they were continuing to treat cases of malaria, tetanus and unspecified gastrointestinal infections at St Francis de Sales Hospital in Port-au-Prince. One team member who is also a surgeon expressed concern over the recent deaths of three individuals due to tetanus, noting the need for increased vaccinations for the Haitian population.

properties.title: Forced removal of 1200 people from Villa Manrese, Haiti
properties.description:
Not Yet Classified &mdash; Haiti<br/>Back ground:
I am a retired Firefighter doing some relief work in Haiti. I have a home in North Carolina but am living in the Dominican republic for the last few months.  After the quake I was asked by some doctor friends to lead a trip to do medical work there so on the 4th day after the quake we went in.  I am back in Haiti now preparing for the next visit of the same group. 
Story:
Last night a small camp of 1200 people were forced off the property they were camped on.  This was a camp that we had provided medical help to. This was done at night and with no warning.  1200 people moved out in darkness with no place to go many children many wounded were put out into the night. What is worse it was done by a supposed Catholic group at Villa Manrese.  The people were living behind the building on a flat spot of ground.  They were a very organized group and were in a safe place.  They had a small school there for the children.  They had food that they shared.  The directors name at Villa Manrese is Pere Andre Paul Grraud. I do not know what he knows about this but he was there in the house above the camp.  I have video of before and after this was done. I understand the need to remove the people from the property but the way they went about this must be reported.  This sort of thing has to be addressed and exposed to the world.  These people were treated like cattle and by fellow Haitians of a Catholic group. 

I am leaving Haiti Thursday for the DR but will be back in 2 weeks.  I will gladly share the video with you.

Tom Parsons 
509-3434-7816 Haiti
829-362-0013 in DR

properties.title: Puerto Rico Declares Dengue Epidemic: Implications for Haiti
properties.description: Dengue Fever &mdash; Haiti<br/>Location: Puerto Rico / Haiti Disease Entity: Dengue On Tuesday of this week, Puerto Rican Health officials declared that the island is officially experiencing a dengue epidemic. The announcement was made after the island exceeded the established dengue epidemic threshold counts for three consecutive weeks. Officials blamed unusual environmental conditions in January, including warm temperatures and rain, for the overproliferation of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which transmits dengue viruses. Areas most affected include Caguas and Arecibo on the North Coast, and Fajardo on the East Coast. We previously reported that all four dengue serotypes are circulating and considered hyperendemic in...

properties.title: Heart Attack Death of Nurse in Haiti; One Report Indicates Unknown Illness in Man's Volunteer Group
properties.description: Undiagnosed &mdash; Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance ReportLocation: Haiti, Port-au-Prince Disease Entity: Unknown Many media sources are reporting the heart attack death of a 36 year old American nurse volunteering in Haiti. One report blamed a “mystery illness” for causing the man’s death as well as for making eight out of 12 people in his volunteer group sick. The man died on Monday, March 1st shortly after becoming ill; no symptoms were described referring to his or the other volunteers’ illnesses. The man had no known underlying health conditions prior to his death. Most other reports describe the death as a heart attack and...

properties.title: Heavy Rainfall in Port-au-Prince Results in Muddy Conditions at IDP Camps
properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Operational Context Location: Port-au-Prince Last week, Port-au-Prince received heavy rain on March 4th resulting in stagnant water collection in many areas impart due to drainage ditches clogged with debris. An internally displaced persons (IDP) camp located on the Del Mar golf course in Port-au-Prince holding approximately 60,000 earthquake survivors received precipitation turning ground conditions into mud. Individuals residing in the camp describe having limited access to clean water and medical care, and no degree of sanitation infrastructure. properties.title: Surveillance Confusion: Measles Versus Chickenpox
properties.description: Measles, Chicken Pox &mdash; Haiti<br/>Over the years we have encountered linguistic ambiguities that tend to be misleading. One example is the Arabic language uses similar words to describe both chickenpox and smallpox. Every time this particular word appeared, analysts would become immediately concerned smallpox was once again in the world- when it was a translation and cultural nuance problem. Here in Haiti we have discovered a similar issue, where the word "rougeole (French) / sarampion (Kreyol)" is used to describe both measles and chickenpox. So this resolves the confusion where we had Haitian physicians insisting multiple cases of "measles" had shown up in our...

properties.description: Gastroenteritis &mdash; Haiti<br/>Here in our camp the newcomers have within 24 hours acquired the same vomiting +/- diarrhea seen in every other group that comes here. Prevalence remains around 30%. Several of our members are smokers- nearly all of them have bronchitis, two of which are on antibiotics and inhalers and one severe enough to require a steroid pulse and multi-day therapy. Probable COPD. All of the individuals had spent time at sea level in the city where the air quality is much worse. properties.title: Sanitation in Haiti's IDP Camps: A Visual Review
properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Haiti<br/>We have referenced the water and sanitation challenges in Haiti several times in this blog. Here we present visuals, walking you from the IDP camp latrine to the canals in Port-au-Prince that lead to the sea. These pictures were taken days ago. Drainage ditches such as this attempt to direct water flow away from latrines. During significant rainfall, water flows over the ditches, floods the latrines, and raw sewage instead is carried downhill. The same drainage ditch, downhill from the latrines with raw sewage and garbage. Nearby, children play in bare feet, some of whom are naked: Raw sewage, garbage,...

properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Haiti<br/>A comprehensive acknowledgment by multiple international agencies of the multiple situation reports and ground assessments by the Haiti Epidemic Advisory System was finally published by The Lancet. Our high level of concern and EMERGENCY APPEAL remains valid. International agencies acknowledged the following: Singular concern about diarrheal disease, with potential for "explosive epidemics" [CDC] Acknowledgment that children (7 of them reported, with an unknown additional number likely not reported) have died of diarrhea since the earthquake [Haiti Ministry of Health] "The [sanitation] needs are overwhelming" [UNICEF] Sphere standards have not been met [UNICEF] "We're very concerned about the rainy season... [and]...

properties.title: REQUEST URGENT
properties.description:
Not Yet Classified &mdash; Pétionville, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Object: REQUEST FOR SHELTER - PETION VILLE


NAME OF THE PERSON IN NEED: MEME SELVANDIEU - Pr&amp;Atilde;&amp;copy;sident/ Fondateur de la Fondation Rocher du Salut d&#039;Haiti (FROCSAH)

CONTACT:  PHONE  00 (509) 3 454-4078       EMAIL meme_selvandieu@yahoo.fr

LOCALIZATION: PLACE DE SAINT PIERRE - PETION VILLE - PORT AU PRINCE (HAITI)

REQUEST: SHELTER FOR 30 PEOPLE, ASSISTANCE FOR 200 FAMILIES INCLUDING FOOD, MEDICINE AND CLOTHES, TENTS


FULL TEXT:

Good-morning,

My name is Meme Selvandieu, Pr&amp;Atilde;&amp;copy;sident/ Fondateur de la Fondation Rocher du Salut d&#039;Haiti (FROCSAH).

I found your contact searching on the Internet http://helphaitiheal.wordpress.com/shelters-camps/ (Help Haiti Heal) and https://www.cimicweb.org/cmo/haiti/Pages/default.aspx (CMO Haiti) and with the help of two Italian friends abroad (Mauro Annarumma - Doctor in the Italian Army mauro.annarumma@gmail.com and Raphael Broniatowski - Volonteer in the Italian Red Cross raphael.bro@cripadova.it)


I&#039;m writing you to request assistance for 200 families, including mine.

We are 30 people without shelter and assistance since January 12th. The other ones need food, medicines and clothes.


The friends I have contacted in Italy are trying to get in touch with the Italian Delegation of the Red Cross in Haiti through its headquarter in Rome but time is passing and we haven&#039;t received any help yet.

I understand you may be too busy to treat directly our kind of request but maybe you can tell us about new distributions of tents and  reliefs in P&amp;Atilde;&amp;copy;tion-Ville and where they are suppose to happen.

We all thank you very much for any kind of help you could give us.

We will be waiting for an answer.

properties.title: Preparing For A Possible Crisis: Pediatric Diarrheal Disease
properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Haiti<br/>Sent to the UN Cluster System and the broader Haiti responder community on 28 March @ 0538 GMT Greetings, The meteorological forecast for next week calls for thunderstorms beginning this Wednesday and lasting at least through the following Tuesday. We will follow the forecasts closely as this time draws near. We are all seriously concerned about an increase in diarrheal disease, specifically in children. It has already been documented that diarrheal disease is a major cause of morbidity and mortality both before the earthquake and after. We have observed apparent ‘bumps’ in diarrheal disease incidence following periods of sustained rainfall,...

properties.title: Medical Professional Reports Dehydration and Gastrointestinal Illness Primary Issue
properties.description: Gastroenteritis &mdash; Cité Soleil, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Cite Soleil, Port-au-Prince, Haiti Disease Entity: Non-specific gastrointestinal illness On March 28th, reports from a physician based in a Cite Soleil area hospital indicate dehydration and gastrointestinal illnesses continue to be the primary cause of morbidity among earthquake survivors living in temporary shelters; however, mortality due to dehydration and gastrointestinal conditions has remained low. Moreover, malaria cases are reported to be increasing as rainfall frequency and accumulation escalate. The interviewed physician noted that there is still a shortage of diagnostic equipment and health professionals available in Port-au-Prince.

properties.title: Cases of Diarrheal Disease Reported in Bellanton IDP Camp
properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Bellanton, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Bellanton, Haiti Disease Entity: Non-specified diarrheal disease A survey carried out at the Bellanton IDP camp located just due west of Savane Blonde identified cases of non-specified diarrheal disease, vomiting, febrile illness, individuals with sore eyes and women with vaginal infections suspected to be caused from exposure to contaminated water. The IDP camp at this location houses 580 families and is reported to be experiencing shortages of shelter-building material, food and clean water.

properties.title: Commentary- (New York Times) "A Project for Haiti: The Eradication of Two Diseases"
properties.description: Malaria, Filariasis &mdash; Haiti<br/>In a recent Letter to the Editor, Dr. Donald Hopkins, the Carter Center Vice President in charge of health programs argues eloquently and precisely for the eradication of malaria and lymphatic filariasis in Haiti. This is certainly a worthy objective to put forth to the world for Haiti. His argument was one of economics- that neighboring Dominican Republic lost 200M in tourism revenue in 2004 due to an epidemic of malaria. At Praecipio International, the Intercept Team is figuratively sitting on the tarmac ready to redeploy on a moment's notice to Haiti. We are imminently about to issue a WARNING...

properties.description: Diarrhea, Environmental &mdash; Haiti<br/>Updated 1534 GMT, 3 APR 2010 Updates to the text are noted in blue. Tactical Ops. Returned from Port-au-Prince. The operational biosurveillance team is grounded in the States pending funding via Emergency Appeal. Our objective is to identify those infectious diseases that may abruptly overwhelm the ad hoc medical infrastructure or be perceived by the Haitian public to be unusual or unexpected. In other words, identification and prioritization of those infectious diseases that may become a crisis or disaster. Our proposed operational activities include: stockpiling diarrheal disease countermeasures in preparation for potential crisis conditions expanding the informal contact network to...

properties.title: Status Report: Infectious Disease Patterns in Port-au-Prince
properties.description: Diarrhea, Malaria &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Port-au-Prince, Haiti Disease Entity: Multiple The Health Director in Haiti for Merlin reports treating more than 200 patients in their mobile clinics per day who originate from remote areas of Port-au-Prince including Allegre, Petit Savane, Ticoma and Vallue. Medical ailments observed among the patient population include diarrhea, skin infections, anemia and malaria. This appears to be baseline and a stable profile. We have seen similar reports from multiple sites throughout the city. The HEAS broader community of public health authorities, NGOs and individual responders have indicated diarrheal/waterborne and vectorborne disease patterns remain stable. Since escalating...

properties.title: Volunteer Nurse Reports Primary Illness Among Earthquake-Affected Children is Pneumonia
properties.description: Pneumonia &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Port-au-Prince, Haiti Disease Entity: Pneumonia A registered nurse who returned to California this week after volunteering in Haiti for a two-week period reports that the primary cause of illness and death among earthquake-affected children she evaluated was pneumonia. In previously issued SitReps and Field Reports we have documented pneumonia among ground responders and the Haitian pediatric population, with recorded mortality primarily among infants. Due to the continued limited diagnostic capability in Haiti, etiology of the observed respiratory disease remains unknown. Formal medical surveillance conducted by MSPP (the Haiti Ministry of Health, supported by PAHO and...

properties.title: Increased Prevalence of Malaria Reported in Croix-des-Bouquets
properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Haiti<br/>We have received this report from Croix-des-Bouquets, Departement de l'Ouest (the greater PAP area). The source of the information is of very high credibility. A couple of things to note when interpreting this information: 1. We do have the expectation of seeing an increase in malaria cases as happens this time of year routinely. 2. We expect an increase above what is typically seen due to crowded conditions in the IDP camps. 3. These findings would therefore not be considered unexpected. 4. These are findings from a single point location (i.e. a single clinic's cachement area), so generalization to the...

properties.title: Contamination of the Water Supply: A Persistent Problem
properties.description: Waterborne Illness &mdash; Pétionville, Haiti<br/>This message came from an environmental health team evaluating the water supply at the Petionville IDP camp yesterday. It highlights a serious challenging in maintaining a protected water supply to the public: The tests taken at the source of the water (ie the water bladders) passed. The water at the camp household level failed (testing positive for fecal coliform when taken from the drinking glass, after transported to the shelter and manipulated). This would not be a surprise in any camp in Haiti at the moment, but underscores the fact that the handling of water post delivery (the containers used...

properties.title: WFP Assesses Food Security Situation is Deteriorating in Haiti
properties.description: Not Yet Classified &mdash; Haiti<br/>WFP has released its latest assessment of the food security situation in Haiti, indicating a deteriorating situation. It is important to note this assessment does not appear to be inclusive of updated information for March. The concerns from a biosurveillance perspective relate to The potential for a shift in demand for protein sources. While the Ministry of Agriculture and USSOUTHCOM took the initiative to vaccinate livestock for anthrax, there are over 2 million estimated goats this vaccination campaign did not cover. Goats are considered a delicacy by the Haitians but are not eaten due to fear of repercussion by the...

properties.title: Tension Levels in Haiti
properties.description: Conflict &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Haiti<br/>The below report was received this evening, indicative of the tension levels in Haiti: 07APR10 Through our network of contacts, we received a report of a forceful removal of IDP camp in Caradeux Delmas 75, Port au Prince. Shortly after 4:15pm [we] arrived to assess the situation and interview members of the community in order to better understand what the people living in the tent camp were facing. The encampment is comprised of four separately named, yet conjoined, camps; Camp Benediction, CCTT, Camp Canaan and Refugee Camp. The exact number of IDP’s is not yet known, but we will attempt...

properties.title: Increase in Acute Respiratory Infections and the Enigma of the H1N1 Pandemic
properties.description: Swine Flu H1N1 &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Two nights ago Port au Prince saw over an inch of rain, another inch the following night, and 2-4 inches expected between 13-14 April. Current HEAS alert levels stand. One of the reporting sites noticed a "definite upswing in respiratory infections", consistent with what we have seen previously during sustained periods of rain. Morbidity but not mortality seen. As has been discussed, a pandemic wave of H1N1 has not been documented in Haiti yet. It is not known if this is an artifact of poorly resourced public health surveillance prior to the earthquake or whether there is some form of...

properties.title: Outbreak of Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO) in Croix des Missions
properties.description: Fever &mdash; Croix des Missions, Ouest, Haiti<br/>From one of the HEAS partners: We were at a camp about 2 miles north of the airport today, Croix des Missions. We had received a report of a fever related illness. We interviewed two of the camp leadership on this. They reported a generalized outbreak of a fever illness, accompanied by vomiting and weakness. They said the afflicted were down in bed for several days, they also said if one person in a household got it the rest of the house got it also. There was no sanitation at this camp of about 2500 souls, and no medical support....

properties.title: Haiti Epidemic Advisory System (HEAS) SitRep: UPDATED 12 APR
properties.description: Diarrhea &mdash; Haiti<br/>Updated 2339 GMT, 12 APR 2010 Updates to the text are noted in blue. Tactical Ops. Returned from Port-au-Prince. The operational biosurveillance team is grounded in the States pending funding via Emergency Appeal. Our objective is to identify those infectious diseases that may abruptly overwhelm the ad hoc medical infrastructure or be perceived by the Haitian public to be unusual or unexpected. In other words, identification and prioritization of those infectious diseases that may become a crisis or disaster. Our proposed operational activities include: stockpiling diarrheal disease countermeasures in preparation for potential crisis conditions expanding the informal contact network to...

properties.title: Suicide Surveillance
properties.description: Not Yet Classified &mdash; Haiti<br/>Over the years, we have found medical surveillance systems pick up on non-infectious disease events. Although we try to keep reporting focused, every now and then non-infectious disease events are too important to filter out. Here we report suicides: [Carrefour] Report by medical personnel of 6 attempted suicides by chlorine ingestion over the past couple of weeks. [Petionville] Attempted suicide by Haitian nurse. These reports likely are the tip of the iceberg and represent an indicator for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

properties.title: Croix des Bouquets: More Malaria Reported
properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Croix des Bouquets, Ouest, Haiti<br/>On 8 APR, a credible source reported their clinic in Croix des Bouquets had seen a large number of malaria cases for March. They have reported seeing as high a case load for April and will provide updates. They commented, With three tent cities close by, standing water in the roads, a open canal running through and everybody sleeping in tents or outside it should not be a surprise that we have a problem. April is shaping up to be as bad as March [referencing malaria case counts]. At the Health Cluster meeting several days after the 8 APR report,...

properties.title: Cite Soleil- High Level of Malaria Reported
properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Cité Soleil, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report has been received by a highly credible source laboratory positive (by rapid test and blood smear) malaria was discovered in 21 of 97 patients seen in Cite Soleil this week. Both children and adults were affected. To date, officials have not confirmed an increase of laboratory confirmed malaria in the greater Port-au-Prince area.

properties.title: Infectious Disease-Related Mortality in Port-au-Prince
properties.description: Malaria, Typhoid, Diarrhea &mdash; Port-au-Prince General Hospital <br/>Cerebral malaria and suspected typhoid in adults still listed as top causes of infectious disease-related mortality at the Port au Prince General Hospital. This has been the case for approximately the last month. No abrupt upticks in infectious disease. Cross-check with staff operating out of General Hospital who attend a field clinic said they were seeing mild diarrhea but no evidence of an abrupt increase. ORS was being handed out for mild cases.

properties.title: Physician at Port-au-Prince General Hospital Reports Concern Over Tuberculosis
properties.description: Tuberculosis &mdash; Port-au-Prince General Hospital <br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Port-au-Prince, Haiti Disease Entity: Tuberculosis A physician from the United States volunteering at Port-au-Prince General Hospital reports concern over tuberculosis activity among internally displaced persons treated at the medical facility. Approximately 300 individuals seek treatment at the hospital each day, of which typically four are diagnosed with tuberculosis. The physician noted that it is commonplace for infected individuals to wait until their condition is severe before obtaining medical care. When tuberculosis cases delay seeking medical care there is an increased risk of transmission to close contacts. A recent publication in the New England Journal of...

properties.title: Clinic Reported Strained Due to Malaria Case Load: Possible Elevation of Alert Level
properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Haiti<br/>We have received a preliminary report of a clinic strained by malaria case load in Port au Prince. If this is confirmed, we will evaluate whether this event represents an IDIS Category 3 event. The implications of an IDIS Cat 3 event will be the need to re-categorize malaria in Port au Prince as a confirmed disruptor agent, and elevate the alert level to a WATCH. We previously reported blood smear and RDT confirmed malaria increases in Croix des Bouquets on 8 APR and 14 APR and Cite Soleil on 15 APR. We have referred these sites to a ground...

properties.title: American Red Cross Reports Seeing an Increase in Malaria
properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Haiti<br/>From NPR: Ms. DeFRANCIS: There are nine million people in Haiti and 1.3 million homeless in Port-au-Prince. So it's a lot to reach. Now, one other thing that the American Red Cross is doing is we're doing a lot of education around malaria. Unfortunately, we are seeing an increase in malaria in Haiti, and what we're distributing, obviously, with all of our relief supplies are mosquito nets. And we're encouraging people, teaching them how to put the nets on and to use them. And these are the kinds of disease prevention measures that we're taking.

properties.title: Elevation of Malaria Alert Level to a WATCH
properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Haiti<br/>The Haiti Epidemic Advisory System has now issued a WATCH for malaria. One of the HEAS community members reported a clinic strained with malaria cases within 2000 meters of General Hospital in downtown PAP. We are evaluating this event as a potential IDIS Category 3 event. Another HEAS community member has reported increased cases of malaria in Petit Goave. The Haitian Ministry of Health has reported the following, The MSPP is currently investigating cases of malaria in the coastal areas of Grand Goave, Petit Goave, Carrefour and Leogane. It is important to note that IDPSS has not been receiving any...

properties.title: Increase in Malaria Reported in the Delmas and Petionville Areas
properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Pétionville, Ouest, Haiti<br/>This now represents a sixth credible source indicating an increase in malaria activity, this time in Delmas and Petionville. This represents (at least) five sites in Port-au-Prince reporting an increase in malaria activity. The alert level will remain at a WATCH for malaria.

properties.title: Increase in Pandemic H1N1 Cases Reported in Cuba: Implications for Elevating the Alert Level in Haiti
properties.description: Swine Flu H1N1 &mdash; Cuba<br/>The National Influenza Virus Labs of the Tropical Medicine Institute Pedro Kouri, Cuba have announced the identification of 93 new cases of pandemic H1N1 and have decided to initiate a vaccination campaign. The Cubans have indicated an increase in cases over the last 5 weeks. We have maintained an ADVISORY for pandemic H1N1 in Haiti for several weeks due to the following concerns: A consistently retracting medical infrastructure due to funding struggles, now overlapping with a specific strategy to hand off assets to the Haitian medical community; this is a very fragile medical infrastructure that is easily overwhelmed. Even more...

properties.title: Escalating Tensions in Port-au-Prince
properties.description: Conflict &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Haiti<br/>A new report has identified growing tension in Cite Soleil, where gangs are reportedly arming themselves over perceived discrepancies between international donations and visible benefit to the poorest communities in the city. One of the HEAS community members was forced to cancel operations in Cite Soleil due to these escalating tensions. The social order-health security nexus risk was highlighted multiple times by HEAS beginning on 11 FEB. We assess an uncontrolled infectious disease crisis involving diarrheal disease, malaria, or pandemic H1N1 may further exacerbate the security situation.

properties.title: Suspected Cases of Leptospirosis Reported at PAP General Hospital
properties.description: Leptospirosis &mdash; Port-au-Prince General Hospital <br/>Several cases of suspected leptospirosis were reported at PAP General Hospital, reflective of clinical suspicion versus laboratory confirmation. Current environmental conditions are conducive for leptospirosis transmission in Haiti, particularly in flooded IDP camps with open refuse and contact with rodent infested waters. Leptospirosis is underreported in Haiti and is not assessed to be a disruptive agent.

properties.title: Dengue Advisory Issued in the US for Relief Workers Returning From Haiti
properties.description: Dengue Fever &mdash; United States<br/>CDC issued an advisory on April 27th for dengue infection among relief workers traveling from Haiti to the United States. We had received reports of dengue infection in military and civilian relief workers returning to the US in February. At that point, it was an issue easily handled at the physician-patient level. Speculation suggests the timing of this particular advisory may reflect a concern not only of seeing more cases in returning relief workers but seasonal mosquito emergence in the US- particularly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus. The salient concern here is whether returning dengue-viremic relief workers, if bitten by...

properties.title: IDP Surveillance System Collapsed
properties.description: Dengue Fever &mdash; Haiti<br/>Today it was announced insufficient data was received by the Ministry of Health to compile the Week 17 IDP Surveillance System (IDPSS) report. This is indicative of the ongoing collapse of the formal medical surveillance capability in Haiti. The challenges to formal medical surveillance were identified in HEAS Situation Reports on 2 Feb, 8 Feb, 16 Feb, 20 Feb, 1 Mar, 13 Mar, 18 Mar, 3 Apr, 8 Apr, 12 Apr, 18 Apr, and 26 Apr. Formal medical surveillance is extremely difficult to implement in post-disaster environments and certainly in the context of a disaster as large as observed in...

properties.title: Confirmed Diphtheria Reported in Port-au-Prince
properties.description: Diphtheria &mdash; Port-au-Prince General Hospital <br/>One of the HEAS partners has reported a confirmed case of diphtheria who is intubated at PAP General Hospital. After hours of searching, the sole source of immunoglobin for the patient was found at PROMESS. Nearly all of the major hospitals were queried, major NGOs, multiple clinics and the Haitian Ministry of Health- no one was able to tell the responding medical team where the immunoglobulin was located. All exposures were provided prophylaxis and vaccinations. Contacts indicated other cases of diphtheria have been reported, however specifics were not disclosed. Haiti recently experienced cases of diphtheria: [From the Haiti Epidemic Advisory...

properties.title: Diphtheria in Port au Prince: CORRECTION
properties.description: Diphtheria &mdash; Port-au-Prince General Hospital <br/>Correction to the posting on diphtheria from yesterday, from the referring physician: A case of suspected (was swabbed by national laboratory but have not heard back) diphtheria was diagnosed yesterday [by clinical suspicion]. By clinical exam and clinical course he has diphtheria. He has grey psuedomembranes on both tonsils and posterior palate, tachypnea, development of stridor and hypoxia requiring intubation, fever, tachycardia and sepsis. He had a fever and sore throat for 6 days.

properties.title: Red Cross Volunteer Reports Malaria Primary Health Threat in Petit Goâve
properties.description: Malaria &mdash; Petit Goâve, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Report Type: Surveillance Report Location: Petit Goave, Haiti Disease Entity: Malaria A member of the International Federation of Red Cross Red Crescent working in Petit Goâve reports that malaria is now the primary health issue among earthquake survivors, noting that approximately 30 percent of patients being treated are diagnosed with malaria. On April 21st we elevated the alert status for malaria to a WATCH following multiple, credible reports of steadily increasing prevalence in several foci of Port-au-Prince. Further information can be found by accessing the latest SitRep for Haiti.

properties.title: Pediatric Suspected Diphtheria Case Dies at PAP General Hospital
properties.description: Diphtheria &mdash; Port-au-Prince General Hospital <br/>The HEAS community previously reported on a case of clinically diagnosed diphtheria in a boy from the Petionville Country Club IDP camp who required intubation and was transferred to PAP General Hospital. Today community members reported the boy has died. This unfortunate fatality reveals several key issues: Vaccination coverage in IDP camps remains a challenge, as is validation of vaccination status. Social network-based infectious disease event reporting captured this report during a time when the IDPSS had become non-functional due to lack of data inputs. Report of the diphtheria case required immediate, time-sensitive response not only for the patient but...

properties.title: Health official: No sign of Haiti diphtheria spike
properties.description:
Diphtheria &mdash; Haiti<br/> Last updated May 9, 2010 4:12 p.m. PT 
 Health official: No sign of Haiti diphtheria spike 
 THE ASSOCIATED PRESS 
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- A 15-year-old boy has died of diphtheria in Haiti, but there is no evidence the bacterial disease is spreading in the earthquake-ravaged country, U.N. health officials said Sunday. 
The boy, a survivor of the Jan. 12 earthquake, died last week despite receiving antitoxin treatments, said Anshu Banerjee, an official with the World Health Organization.

properties.title: WHO Officials Do Not Find Evidence of Diphtheria Spread
properties.description: Diphtheria &mdash; Haiti<br/>The formal disease surveillance system, the IDP Surveillance System (IDPSS), remains down and not producing reports. World Health Organization officials have indicated they see no evidence of diphtheria transmission, however confidence in that observation should be challenged. There remains clear limitations to infectious disease surveillance, difficulty in conducting investigations in the multitude of IDP camps, inability to fully validate vaccination status, questionable vaccination coverage, and limited operational coupling between infectious disease event warning and rapid response. The question remains how the child became exposed to diphtheria in the first place, and why there was such a time delay in locating...

properties.title: Civil Unrest: Implications For Public Health Operations
properties.description: Diphtheria, Malaria &mdash; Haiti<br/>We have been monitoring the civil unrest and political stability situation in Haiti for some time now, which began with the first rumblings in the camps weeks ago, isolated civil unrest in Cite Soleil, Jacmel, Cap Haitien, and Leogane, and now with demonstrations downtown. Time limits on Preval's Administration have drawn nigh with a rise in political opposition. The logical question could be asked about what the status of the Ministry of Health will be as well as its operations related to infectious disease surveillance and response. A disruption in the political environment will likely result in further operational disruption...

properties.title: Diphtheria cases in Haitian camp prompt UN-backed emergency vaccination
properties.description:
Diphtheria &mdash; Port-au-Prince, Ouest, Haiti<br/> A Haitian camp 
 18 May 2010 &#150 
 United Nations agencies are helping health authorities in Haiti carry out an emergency vaccination campaign after an outbreak of diphtheria in the capital, Port-au-Prince, a spokesperson with the world body said today. 
Cases of the disease were first reported on Saturday in Camp Batimat in Cité Soleil district, one of the settlements housing people displaced by the January earthquake, Christiane Berthiaume, spokesperson for the UN Childrens Fund ( UNICEF 
), told reporters in Geneva.

properties.title: CLARIFICATION: Diphtheria in Haiti
properties.description: Diphtheria &mdash; Cité Soleil, Ouest, Haiti<br/>Yesterday's report contained mention of an HEAS partner who reported a suspected outbreak of diphtheria at the same location, Cite Soleil as mentioned by the Unicef representative to the press in Geneva. We have come to understand that particular report does not refer to Cite Soleil but rather "Camp Canaan" adjacent to Camp Corail, intersection of Highway One and Nine, 12 miles north of PAP. This should be considered an unconfirmed report. Authorities have been appraised of this discrepancy.

properties.title: Continued Miscommunication Between Public Health and Medical Responders in Haiti
properties.description: Diphtheria &mdash; Haiti<br/>We have had a request for information from one of the HEAS partners regarding the status of new identification of diphtheria cases. They are making decisions to scale back diphtheria vaccinations due to supply / cost considerations and were wondering if anyone had information to suggest diphtheria activity remains "live". The IDPSS continues to exclude reporting of diphtheria, despite Unicef's international declaration of an activated emergency vaccination campaign. This reflects ongoing disconnect between formal syndromic surveillance and operational reality. Minimal communication between public health and those who are providing care to the Haitians continues to impair proper, coordinated response.

properties.title: UPDATE: Security Situation in Haiti
properties.description: Conflict &mdash; Haiti<br/>The MINUSTAH JOTC reported on May 25th (this is the formal report stemming from the Flash Report we posted two days ago) that, The overall security situation in Haiti has become volatile, with sporadic anti-government demonstrations by the political opposition. A recent rekindling of criminal violence has also provoked renewed concerns. On 24 May, five demonstrations were reported. In the first, in Gonaïves, a demonstration organized by teachers from ‘l’Association des Educateurs de Dessalines’ demanded the recognition of the education system in Marchand Dessalines locality by the Government. A second, in Pétion-Ville, brought together around 100 persons calling on government...

properties.title: Two Outbreaks of Tuberculosis in Florida Triggers Public Outcry Against Haitian Immigration
properties.description: Tuberculosis &mdash; Florida<br/>Media report in Palm Beach County, Florida that two separate elementary schools have outbreaks of tuberculosis. Parents at Seminole Ridge High School in Loxahatchee and Orchard View Elementary in Delray Beach have blamed recent immigrant Haitian students for the outbreaks. This is an example of public outcry leveled at public health in the context of unexpected or non-routine pediatric infectious disease threats. Similar behavior was observed in many countries, including the United States, during the emergence of pandemic H1N1 in elementary schools. Such outcry may evolve into public demonstrations or localized acts of violence. Demonstrations in the United States are...

properties.title: Two Outbreaks of Tuberculosis in Florida Triggers Public Outcry Against Haitian Immigration
properties.description: Tuberculosis &mdash; Haiti<br/>Media report in Palm Beach County, Florida that two separate elementary schools have outbreaks of tuberculosis. Parents at Seminole Ridge High School in Loxahatchee and Orchard View Elementary in Delray Beach have blamed recent immigrant Haitian students for the outbreaks. This is an example of public outcry leveled at public health in the context of unexpected or non-routine pediatric infectious disease threats. Similar behavior was observed in many countries, including the United States, during the emergence of pandemic H1N1 in elementary schools. Such outcry may evolve into public demonstrations or localized acts of violence. Demonstrations in the United States are...

properties.title: Typhoid Outbreak Reported in Camp Acra-Delmas, PAP
properties.description: Typhoid &mdash; Haiti<br/>A total of 82 suspected, 31 of which were confirmed, typhoid cases were reported by the American Refugee Committee in Camp Acra from June 22 to 25. Fifty-two of the suspected cases were above the age of 5 years old. The outbreak appears to be concluding now, however transmission in areas outside of the camp remains uncertain. This is not an unexpected finding, as typhoid is endemic in Haiti. This event is representative of an IDIS Category 1 at this point.

properties.title: Caribbean thousand infection of dengue fever outbreak
properties.description: Dengue Fever &mdash; Haiti<br/>加勒比海沿岸诸国眼下遭遇登革热疫情,数十人死亡,数以千计民众确诊感染这种由蚊虫叮咬传染的地区性急性传染病。　多米尼加、波多黎各、特立尼达和多巴哥等地卫生部门紧急行动,呼吁民众大力灭蚊。 　美联社18日援引多米尼加公共卫生部长包蒂斯塔·罗哈斯·戈麦斯的话报道,超过5000人确诊罹患登革热。截至18日,多米尼加已有至少27名患者死亡。 　 波多黎各疾病控制和预防中心部门主管凯·托马舍克说,截至7月中旬,至少5人死于这种传染病;医疗机构报告收治大约6300个疑似病例。 　泛美卫生组织公布的最新统计显示,截至6月上旬,加勒比海地区报告病例数超过1.67万。 　各国卫生部门官员说,由于今年天气暖和、提前进入雨季,蚊虫数量激增,导致经由蚊虫叮咬传染的登革热疫情暴发。 (本文来源:京华时报。

properties.title: The Canadian Press: UN: Haiti's cholera outbreak is easing but some rural areas see spike in deaths
properties.description:
Cholera — Grande Anse, Sud-Est, Haiti UN: Haiti's cholera outbreak is easing but some rural areas see spike in deaths 
–
 3 hours ago 
GENEVA — Haiti's cholera outbreak appears to be diminishing nationwide but the death rate in rural areas remains alarmingly high, the United Nations said Friday. 
The mixed picture comes from Haitian government figures citing 231,070 reported cases and 4,549 deaths since the epidemic began in October.
